remixlab.dandelion.geom

Class Quat

  • java.lang.Object
    • remixlab.dandelion.geom.Quat
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Linkable, Rotation, Copyable

    public class Quat
extends Object
implements Linkable, Rotation
    A 3D Rotation is a 4 element unit quaternion represented by single precision floating point x,y,z,w coordinates.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      float[] quat
      The x, y, z, and w coordinates of the Quat represented as a public array.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Quat()
      Constructs and initializes a Quat to (0.0,0.0,0.0,1.0), i.e., an identity rotation.

      Convenience constructor that simply calls this(q, true)

      Constructs and initializes a Quat from the array of length 4.

      Constructs a Quat from the given Euler angles.

      Constructs and initializes a Quat from the specified xyzw coordinates.

      Constructs a Quat from a (supposedly correct) 3x3 rotation matrix given in the upper left 3x3 sub-matrix of the Mat.

      Copy constructor.

      Constructs and initializes a Quat from the specified rotation axis (non null) and angle (in radians).

      Constructs a Quat that will rotate from the from direction to the to direction.
      Quat(Vec X, Vec Y, Vec Z)
      Constructs a Quat from the three rotated vectors of an orthogonal basis.

      • dotProduct

        public final float dotProduct(Quat b)
        Returns the "dot" product of this Quat and b:

        this.quat[0] * b.x + this.quat[1] * b.y + this.quat[2] * b.z + this.quat[3] * b.quat[3]

        Parameters:
        b - the Quat

      • dot

        public static final float dot(Quat a,
                              Quat b)
        Returns the "dot" product of a and b:

        a.x * b.x + a.y * b.y + a.z * b.z + a.quat[3] * b.quat[3]

        Parameters:
        a - the first Quat
        b - the second Quat

      • multiplyInverse

        public final void multiplyInverse(Quat q1)
        Multiplies this Quat by the inverse of Quat q1 and places the value into this Quat (i.e., this = this * q^-1). The value of the argument Quat is preserved.
        Parameters:
        q1 - the other Quat

      • multiplyInverse

        public static final Quat multiplyInverse(Quat q1,
                                         Quat q2)
        Returns the product of Quat q1 by the inverse of Quat q2 (i.e., q1 * q2^-1). The value of both argument quaternions is preserved.
        Parameters:
        q1 - the first Quat
        q2 - the second Quat

      • inverse

        public final Quat inverse()
        Returns the inverse Quat (inverse rotation).

        The result has a negated axis() direction and the same angle().

        A composition of a Quat and its inverse() results in an identity function. Use invert() to actually modify the Quat.

        Specified by:
        inverse in interface Rotation
        See Also:
        invert()

      • fromAxisAngle

        public void fromAxisAngle(Vec axis,
                          float angle)
        Sets the Quat as a rotation of axis and angle (in radians).

        The axis does not need to be normalized. A null axis will result in an identity Quat.

        Parameters:
        axis - the Vec representing the axis
        angle - the angle in radians

      • fromEulerAngles

        public void fromEulerAngles(Vec angles)
        Convenience function that simply calls fromEulerAngles(angles.vec[0], angles.vec[1], angles.vec[2]).
        See Also:
        fromEulerAngles(float, float, float), eulerAngles()

      • fromEulerAngles

        public void fromEulerAngles(float roll,
                            float pitch,
                            float yaw)
        Converts Euler rotation angles roll, pitch and yaw, respectively defined to the x, y and z axes, to this Quat. In the convention used here these angles represent a composition of extrinsic rotations (rotations about the reference frame axes), which is also known as taitBryanAngles() (See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler_angles and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tait-Bryan_angles). eulerAngles() performs the inverse operation.

        Each rotation angle is converted to an axis-angle pair, with the axis corresponding to one of the Euclidean axes. The axis-angle pairs are converted to quaternions and multiplied together. The order of the rotations is: y,z,x which follows the convention found here: http://www.euclideanspace.com/maths/geometry/rotations/euler/index.htm.

        See Also:
        eulerAngles()

      • taitBryanAngles

        public Vec taitBryanAngles()
        Same as eulerAngles().

      • eulerAngles

        public Vec eulerAngles()
        Converts this Quat to Euler rotation angles roll, pitch and yaw in radians. fromEulerAngles(float, float, float) performs the inverse operation. The code was adapted from: http://www.euclideanspace.com/maths/geometry/rotations/conversions/ quaternionToEuler/index.htm.

        Attention: This method assumes that this Quat is normalized.

        Returns:
        the Vec holding the roll (x coordinate of the vector), pitch (y coordinate of the vector) and yaw angles (z coordinate of the vector). Note: The order of the rotations that would produce this Quat (i.e., as with fromEulerAngles(roll, pitch, yaw)) is: y,z,x.
        See Also:
        fromEulerAngles(float, float, float)

      • fromTo

        public void fromTo(Vec from,
                   Vec to)
        Sets the Quat as a rotation from the from direction to the to direction.

        Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. The selected axis is usually orthogonal to from and to, minimizing the rotation angle. This method is robust and can handle small or almost identical vectors.

        Specified by:
        fromTo in interface Rotation
        See Also:
        fromAxisAngle(Vec, float)

      • fromTo

        public void fromTo(float x1,
                   float y1,
                   float z1,
                   float x2,
                   float y2,
                   float z2)
        Same as fromTo(new Vec(x1,y1,z1), new Vec(x2,y2,z2)).
        See Also:
        fromTo(Vec, Vec)

      • fromMatrix

        public final void fromMatrix(Mat glMatrix)
        Set the Quat from a (supposedly correct) 3x3 rotation matrix given in the upper left 3x3 sub-matrix of the Mat.
        Specified by:
        fromMatrix in interface Rotation
        See Also:
        fromRotatedBasis(Vec, Vec, Vec)

      • fromRotatedBasis

        public final void fromRotatedBasis(Vec X,
                                   Vec Y,
                                   Vec Z)
        Sets the Quat from the three rotated vectors of an orthogonal basis.

        The three vectors do not have to be normalized but must be orthogonal and direct (i,e., X^Y=k*Z, with k>0).

        Specified by:
        fromRotatedBasis in interface Rotation
        Parameters:
        X - the first Vec
        Y - the second Vec
        Z - the third Vec
        See Also:
        fromRotatedBasis(Vec, Vec, Vec), Quat(Vec, Vec)

      • axis

        public final Vec axis()
        Returns the normalized axis direction of the rotation represented by the Quat.

        The result is null for an identity Quat.

        See Also:
        angle()

      • angle

        public final float angle()
        Returns the angle (in radians) of the rotation represented by the Quat.

        This value is always in the range [0-pi]. Larger rotational angles are obtained by inverting the axis() direction.

        Specified by:
        angle in interface Rotation
        Returns:
        rotation angle
        See Also:
        axis()

      • matrix

        public final Mat matrix()
        Returns the Mat which represents the rotation matrix associated with the Quat.
        Specified by:
        matrix in interface Rotation

      • inverseMatrix

        public final Mat inverseMatrix()
        Returns the associated inverse rotation Mat. This is simply matrix() of the inverse().

        Attention: The result is only valid until the next call to inverseMatrix(). Use it immediately (as in applyMatrix(q.inverseMatrix())).

        Specified by:
        inverseMatrix in interface Rotation

      • log

        public final Quat log()
        Returns the logarithm of the Quat.
        See Also:
        exp()

      • exp

        public final Quat exp()
        Returns the exponential of the Quat.
        See Also:
        log()

      • randomQuat

        public static final Quat randomQuat()
        Returns a random unit Quat.

        You can create a randomly directed unit vector using:

        Vec randomDir = new Vec(1.0f, 0.0f, 0.0f);
        randomDir = Quat.multiply(Quat.randomQuat(), randomDir);

      • slerp

        public static final Quat slerp(Quat a,
                               Quat b,
                               float t)
        Wrapper function that simply calls slerp(a, b, t, true).

        See slerp(Quat, Quat, float, boolean) for details.

      • slerp

        public static final Quat slerp(Quat a,
                               Quat b,
                               float t,
                               boolean allowFlip)
        Returns the slerp interpolation of quaternions a and b, at time t.

        t should range in [0,1]. Result is a when t=0 and b when t=1.

        When allowFlip is true (default) the slerp interpolation will always use the "shortest path" between the quaternions' orientations, by "flipping" the source Quat if needed (see negate()).

        Parameters:
        a - the first Quat
        b - the second Quat
        t - the t interpolation parameter
        allowFlip - tells whether or not the interpolation allows axis flip

      • squad

        public static final Quat squad(Quat a,
                               Quat tgA,
                               Quat tgB,
                               Quat b,
                               float t)
        Returns the slerp interpolation of the two quaternions a and b, at time t, using tangents tgA and tgB.

        The resulting Quat is "between" a and b (result is a when t=0 and b for t=1).

        Use squadTangent(Quat, Quat, Quat) to define the Quat tangents tgA and tgB.

        Parameters:
        a - the first Quat
        tgA - the first tangent Quat
        tgB - the second tangent Quat
        b - the second Quat
        t - the t interpolation parameter

      • lnDif

        public static final Quat lnDif(Quat a,
                               Quat b)
        Simply returns log(a. inverse() * b).

        Useful for squadTangent(Quat, Quat, Quat).

        Parameters:
        a - the first Quat
        b - the second Quat

      • squadTangent

        public static final Quat squadTangent(Quat before,
                                      Quat center,
                                      Quat after)
        Returns a tangent Quat for center, defined by before and after quaternions.
        Parameters:
        before - the first Quat
        center - the second Quat
        after - the third Quat

      • squaredNorm

        public static float squaredNorm(Quat q)
        Utility function that returns the squared norm of the Quat.

      • print

        public void print()
        Description copied from interface: Rotation
        Prints orientation data.
        Specified by:
        print in interface Rotation
